author: @minoanlight4545
text: With so much hype about learning to code recently, you would think such videos would have millions of views. But they don't. Hmm...wondering why? Is it because many people give up long before they even get to something such as decorators? However, I see that videos on HTML, JS, CSS, PHP and other web programming languages have significantly more views than videos about Python, Java, C++, C, C#, Ruby...etc. It is like everyone wants to be a web developer.

author: @DlcEnergy
text: pretty useful, but i'd still prefer...  def wrap(item,style): return 'a %s wrapped up box of %s'%(style,item)  def new_gpu(): return wrap(wrap('a new Tesla P100 GPU','beautifully'),'horribly')  print(new_gpu())  >> a horribly wrapped up box of a beautifully wrapped up box of a new Tesla P100 GPU

author: @finfan7
text: Love your tutorials, but this time I don't quite get the use. After watching this I get *how* to use decorators, at least syntactically, but not *why*.   Is your code, as written at 2:53, significantly different in a useful way from  def add_wrapping(item):         return 'a wrapped up box of {}'.format(str(item()))  def new_gpu():     return 'a new Tesla P100 GPU!'  print(add_wrapping(new_gpu()))  Decorators seem like a way to run a function on the result of a function by default but, if it's the default, why not make it part of the function (e.g. adding 'A wrapped up box of" inside the new_gpu function)  or, if you wanted to maintain modularity so other things could be 'wrapped,' simply call the function directly? (as in the code above)
